bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Domingo Ramos, March 6, 1941

div1.p: Kean assures Ramos that Hench is correct about the location of Camp Lazear, and gives a little of his own history in Cuba to indicate that he himself has knowledge of the places.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Domingo Ramos, March 6, 1941
div1.opener:
C O P Y
March 6, 1941
His Excellency Dr. Domingo Ramos
Minister of National Defense, Republic of Cuba
My dear Doctor Ramos:
div1.p:
My service in Cuba under General Leonard Wood as Supretendente de
Beneficencia and again under Governor Magoon as Adviser of the Sanitary Dept.
and my personal friendship for both Dr. Carlos Finlay and Dr. Walter Reed
have caused me to take great interest in the research being made by Dr.
Philip S. Hench of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn. into the yellow fever
episode in Cuba at the beginning of this century. It is remarkable that
a physician of his high professional standing and his preoccupations as a
medical author should, in a perfectly disinterested way, devote so much
time and labor and pecuniary expense into the investigation of the details
of the experiments of the Reed Commission in their famous demonstration of
the scientific accuracy of Dr. Finlay's wonderful discovery of the trans-
mission of yellow fever by the mosquito (Aedes Egypti) I visited Camp Lazear
on the San Jose' finca east of the Calzada Real with Major Reed, and I made
the payments, from Insular Funds, of the rent for the land occupied by the
camp, to Senor Ignacio Rojas, as shown by records of which Dr. Hench has
photostat copies. I am also familiar with the location southwest of the
Military Hospital where was located in 1900-1901 the small buildings for
the treatment of yellow fever and other infectious diseases, and which was
across the railroad to La Playa de Marianao from the Hospital. I was myself
a yellow fever patient in one of the huts there in June 1900, being at that
time the Chief Surgeon on the Staff of General Fitzhugh Lee, commanding at
that time the Military Department of Western Cuba. In this place also Dr. Jesse
Lazear died of yellow fever in September, 1900. I am gratified to hear that
the Cuban Government has purchased this small area and will preserve it as
a memorial to him.

So I am able of my own knowledge, Senor Dr. Ramos, to assure you of
the correctness of the facts claimed and established in this matter by Dr.
Hench and I hope that you will give him your approval and aid in the laudable
aims which he has in view.
